1.0  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Freeport McMoRan is the owner and operator of the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  It is the policy of Freeport McMoRan that its employees, environment, property, and the general public be protected from any off-site impacts that may occur as a result of its operations.  To achieve this end, Freeport McMoRan strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations. Freeport McMoRan has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention (e.g., personnel training, safety consideration in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility, etc.).  The company's philosophy is to implement reasonable mitigation measures to eliminate preventable releases of regulated substances as well as non-regulated substances. 
  
The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant activates its emergency response policies to comply with the overall Freeport McMoRan policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel is the highest priority; therefore, all procedures must be implemented in the appropriate manner (e.g., safely executed rescue and medical activities).  Protection of the environment is also a high priority.  Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.

1.2  Facility Description

The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is located approximately 12 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean and approximately 1.5 miles northeast of the Vandenberg Village.  The nearest public road is Harris Grade Road, approximately 0.25 miles to the west.  The facility is relatively remote and bounded by undeveloped private prope

rty.  The facility is fenced in and access is controlled by a locked gate that is manned 24-hours a day.  

The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is a relatively small industrial operation, occupying approximately 20 acres and consists of one Program 3 process. The Gas Plant qualifies for Program 3 because it is subject to the California Occupational Safety and Health  Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (8 CCR 5189).

The facility receives incoming crude oil and gas from an offshore platform (including some gas from onshore fields) and then utilizes several operations to produce natural gas and natural gas liquids for product.  The incoming oil is processed in the oil treating portion of the facility where water and other contaminates are separated from the crude oil before it is shipped via pipeline to a refinery for further processing.  The incoming gas is treated by removing water, hydrogen sulfide, and other heavy hydrocarbon components.  The hydrocarbon liquids which are separated out are sent to pressure vessels for storage before being trucked offsite to distributors.  The dry natural gas from the process is sold as a product.  

1.3  Regulated Substances

Regulated flammable mixtures containing methane, ethane, propane, butane, iso-butane, pentane and iso-pentane are present at the facility.  There are no regulated toxic substances present at the facility in excess of the federal threshold quantities.

1.4  Summary of Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The worst-case release for flammables, as defined in regulation, is a release of flammable materials resulting in a vapor cloud explosion of the maximum inventory of the largest vessel. Even though the normal operating inventory for this equipment is often less than the maximum capacity, and this equipment is protected by high level alarms/shutdowns, pressure relief valves, periodic inspections, and routine monitoring by operating personnel, this maximum inventory must be

assumed to be released in 10 minutes and ignited at the point of release. 

The worst-case release scenario modeled for the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is a release of the entire volume of the flammable material stored in one of two butane/propane 30,000 gallon storage vessels. The Lompoc oil and Gas Plant has a total of three 30,000 gallon vessels located in the southeast corner of the facility, two butane/propane storage vessels as stated above and one vessel containing natural gas liquids. Per 40CFR68.25(b)(1), the greatest amount held in a single vessel shall be used to determine the worst-case release quantity. The worst-case release scenario did not identify and off-site impacts and no impact to public, environmental and residential receptors. 

The alternative release scenario for flammables is a release of a flammable mixture which results in a vapor cloud fire. The alternative release scenario identified no off-site impact. 

1.5  Summary of Accidental Release Prevention Program 

In addition to being subject to RMP requirements the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is subject to the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal-OSHA) Process Safety Management Program (PSM).  Through compliance with the PSM standard (with minor additions) Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant has implemented the requirements of the Program 3 prevention program.  

Compliance with PSM's comprehensive program ensures the integrity of the processes which handle flammable materials.  The objective of the company's PSM Program is to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals.   To control these types of hazards, Freeport McMoRan has developed the necessary expertise, experiences, judgment and proactive initiative within their workforce to properly implement and maintain an effective process safety management program.  An effective PSM program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole chemical process. Using this approach the following components were consider

ed in the evaluation:  1) the process design; 2) process technology; 3) process changes; 4) operational and maintenance activities and procedures; 5) non-routine activities and procedures; 6) emergency preparedness plans and procedures; 7) training programs; and 8) other elements that affect the process.  The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals have been evaluated and strengthened to assure their effectiveness at each level.  PSM is the proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation or prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in process, procedures or equipment.  

1.6  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

In addition to implementing the PSM elements, the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant utilizes specific safety features for the prevention, detection and control of releases of regulated (and other) substances.  Control and detection equipment located in and around the facility to minimize the risk of an accident involving hazardous materials at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant include:

     Relief and/or safety valves
     High temperature alarms and/or shutdowns
     Flame detectors 
     Combustible Gas Detectors
     Smoke Detectors
     Hydrogen Sulfide Monitors
     Fire Protection System
     Emergency Shutdown Systems (ESD)
     Leak Detection System 

1.7  Five-Year Accident History

The EPA's RMP Regulation defines "accident" as the following:

"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold
quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:
     
On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place
(§68.42(a))."

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the

facility's accident history there have been no incidents, as defined in the regulation above, involving a regulated substance at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant in the last five years. 

1.8  Emergency Response Program Summary

Freeport McMoRan developed written emergency response procedures to address all elements that may be encountered during planning, response or follow-up of an emergency at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  These emergency response procedures address releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of fires or explosions.  The procedures address the following issues:  1) various aspects of proper emergency first-aid and medical treatment for exposures; 2) notification of local emergency response agencies; 3) evacuation plans for the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant and methods of accounting for facility personnel after an evacuation; and 4) post-incident cleanup/decontamination requirements.  In addition, the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant follows procedures that address the maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment and alarms. 

Application of the emergency response procedures ensures compliance with the Cal-OSHA Standard 8 CCR 3220 (Emergency Action Plans), and the emergency response element of PSM.  The basic concepts of these emergency procedures are to provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies.  The four elements of this approach are prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery.

1.9 Planned Changes to Improve Safety (On-going)

As a requirement of Santa Barbara County, Freeport McMoRan has performed a Best Available and Safest Technology (BAST) audit of the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  The BAST requirement states that production operations (oil and gas) use the best available and safest technologies wherever failure of equipment would have a significant effect on safety, health, or the environment.  The results of the audit indicate that the facility is in compliance with the letter and spirit
of the BAST regulation.  The audit findings and recommendations are to be reviewed by the Santa Barbara County Systems Safety and Reliability Review Committee for comment.
